title: Expanding Perspectives in BioScience
content: It is a great pleasure to introduce this month's content, which has a heavy focus on policy and practice related to conserving biodiversity. Trackenberg and colleagues discuss the effective management of US coastal fisheries, particularly with regard to preserving habitat where juvenile fish can develop but find a disconnect between research findings and management applications. Kumschick and colleagues make suggestions on how to focus on potentially dangerous alien taxa by developing safe lists for many alien species that are likely not harmful. Finally, O'Neal and colleagues highlight the nearly universal importance of indirect effects in ecological processes, but they note that terminology is often unclear and confusing, hampering efforts to assess the environmental risks of human alteration of the landscape (development). All three of the previous articles conclude with clear policy recommendations. All three of the previous articles conclude with clear policy recommendations.
